Lack enough support: The claim lacks support from cybersecurity, banking, or law enforcement organizations that recommend pressing the cancel button twice to prevent information from being stolen.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that pressing the cancel button twice will cancel any setup by scammers to steal the PIN code, but there is no evidence or expert opinion to support this assumption.
Exist alternative explanation: The expert explains that pressing the cancel button twice or multiple times would make zero difference in preventing scams, as scammers can use keypad overlays to record everything that is pressed.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that pressing the cancel button twice does not provide any additional security against ATM scams, as explained by the expert.
Understate: The claim may understate the complexity and variety of techniques used by scammers at ATMs, as explained by the expert who lists several common methods such as skimming, cash trapping, card trapping, unlimited cash-out, fake keypads, and hidden cameras.
Falters at times: The claim falters by providing a potentially ineffective security measure (pressing the cancel button twice) without sufficient evidence or expert support.
Exaggerate: There is no evidence of exaggeration in the claim.
